children.subject: Thank you for sharing your experience! Appreciate it a lot!

I went to Daniel Zhang's discussions in the morning, and because they started at 9am, there was, at most, 2 people. I also had weekly 1 on 1 teaching sessions that you can sign up for every week, and coordinated so he would also be my tutor. The key is actually watching lecture and identifying everything you don't understand, attempting to figure it out on your own through google, or past readings, or some simple practice problems you can find online. If you still don't understand, write it down and ask on piazza. Then, when you have discussion or your tutoring session, lay them all out. This is why I personally webcast, so I can pause and go back.

I had trouble understanding concepts watching lectures because I felt, a lot of times, concepts were explained without much detail, and then we were expected to understand. By writing down all my questions and trying to figure them out, I was later able to understand the material.

I see he's still a TA for 61C, so I highly recommend asking him for help. And i'm sure there are other TA's that will be great. Labs and office hours tended to be full, but I still encourage you to attend and ask as many questions.

Finding friends to form study groups, maybe reading the textbook, and attempting to learn the material using pictures, or talking out loud, or even creating funny stories around concepts can help. For me, just asking questions was sufficient.

history.content:
Hi! I am taking 61C this semester, but I am totally lost in the lectures. Can anyone share some 61C learning experience?

Thank you!!
history.subject: 61C Study Tips?
